World Languages and Linguistics

Degree

Bachelor of Arts

School

Humanities and Social Sciences

Department

World Languages and Cultures

Program at a Glance

Studying global languages, cultures, and literature gives us a better understanding of our complex and multicultural world. Learning to communicate in different languages is an invaluable skill desirable to employers and translates to almost any career or industry. This major focuses on the science of languages with a concentration in Arabic, French, Italian, Japanese, or Spanish. Our rich curriculum blends the strengths of a liberal arts education with a program of immersive cultural experiences, including study abroad.

ApplyRequest Info

Linguistics Minor

Spanish Minor

Certificates

Spanish for Professional Purposes Certificate Program

Students benefit from: 

  • Small class sizes — to ensure individual attention and extensive use of the target language 
  • Integrated immersive cultural experiences — including trips, speakers, festivals, and performances
  • A weekly oral proficiency hour — offering students a relaxed atmosphere to practice and expand their knowledge of a chosen language in small groups through activities, games, and conversation 
  • First-rate instruction and strong mentorship from expert faculty — help guide academic and career paths
  • Study abroad opportunities — at more than 100 locations through TCNJ’s Center for Global Engagement. 
  • A flexible curriculum that easily accommodates double majors or additional minors — with virtually any other TCNJ academic program of interest
  • Minors in eight different languages — Arabic, Chinese, French, German Studies, Italian, Japanese, Linguistics, Russian Studies, and Spanish

Careers

Our students gain the deep knowledge and practical skills, insights, and experiences that appeal to top employers and graduate schools. Knowledge of other languages and cultures can significantly enhance career opportunities in any field, including business, law, medicine, healthcare, international education, nonprofit, government, technology, marketing, social services, and more.

Top Employers

The AFL-CIO
American Red Cross
The Latin American Legal Defense and Education Fund
School districts, including various New Jersey Model World Language programs

Top Graduate Programs

Michigan State University
Rutgers University
The Universidad deAlcalá (Spain)
University of Minnesota
Villanova University Law School

Course Sequence

The major assumes no previous foreign language study. Even if students enter with no knowledge of a foreign language, they will have ample time to complete the required seven language courses and five linguistics courses. Students entering the major at a higher proficiency level can take a more significant number of upper-level courses in the foreign language. Students will be actively encouraged to complete at least one study abroad semester. They can take three language and linguistics courses for the major and one free elective during their semester abroad.

Heritage Spanish-Speaker Programming

Spanish-speaking students can start their major or minor with a course designed specifically for students raised speaking Spanish. This learning environment, with an emphasis on the Hispanic experience in the U.S., is tailored for students who want to develop fluency and poise, strengthen their writing skills, and raise their proficiency toward professional levels.

Study Abroad Opportunities

Gaining global experience and perspective through immersion in other languages and cultures is integral to our program. Students may choose a credit-bearing program offered by TCNJ or one of many third-party programs provided through TCNJ’s Center for Global Engagement. TCNJ also offers unique study opportunities at Universidad Adolfo Ibanez in Vina del Mar, Chile, as well as faculty-led programs in and around Madrid, Spain, at Universidad de Alcalá de Henares and Universidad Complutense de Madrid.

Active Student Organizations

For additional experience and exposure to languages and cultures of interest, many student-led organizations are on campus to get involved. The WLC department supports and participates in the Chinese Students Association, French Club, German Club, Italian Club, Japanese Student Association, and Spanish Club.

Faculty

Students are guided and instructed by dedicated faculty from diverse cultural backgrounds. Faculty members represent more than ten countries and speak Arabic, Chinese, Danish, English, French, German, Italian, Hebrew, Japanese, Polish, Russian, Spanish, and Yiddish.
